prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I kick my adult ”stepdaughter” out of my house?
New here so if I haven’t understood one of the rules please let me know!

I have a tricky situation I’m going through as of late.  I’m in a long term relationship.  We aren’t technically married, but we live as we are.  After a messy divorce she was never interested in being married again.  We’ve been dating for 8 years now.  I told her that the engagement is the best part so I proposed with both of us understanding that we would never actually get married.  She has an adult daughter who lives with us.  She’s 19. 

My “stepdaughter” and I have never had a good relationship despite my best efforts.  I really gave it everything I could to improve it over the years, but at best she was indifferent to me.  I gave up trying after buying her a car for her 16th birthday and she thanked her mother and didn’t acknowledge me at all even after her mother told her that I alone bought it for her.  

After that I’ve been just waiting her out for the most part.  I’m still kind when I’m around her, but if this is the relationship with me she wants then so be it.  I always assumed that when she turned 18 she would go off to school somewhere.  I was unfortunately wrong.  She instead started working at a salon in town.  She had taken cosmetology in BOCES in high school.  

I thought once she had been working for a bit and had saved enough she would then move out.  Wrong again.  I’ve asked her mother to see what her plans are for the future and if she plans on moving out on her own soon and my wife told me that she just wants to save as much as she can and keep living here.   My fiancé loves having her here, but I’ve been waiting so long to have the house be just my fiancé and I.   

I really feel like I’ve put my time in supporting her daughter and now especially with her having more than enough to move out on her own it’s time to push her out of the nest.  I’m not too concerned with her reaction.   To be blunt I don’t really care how she takes it.   My fiancé will probably be a little upset, but hopefully once the dust clears she will see that it’s for the best.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong for wanting to kick their adult stepdaughter out of the house. 

First, the situation: The author is in a long-term relationship with their fiancé, who is the mother of the 19-year-old stepdaughter. They've been together for 8 years, but aren't married. The stepdaughter lives with them, and the author feels they've tried to build a relationship but it hasn't worked. The stepdaughter isn't moving out, even though she's working and could afford to. The author wants her to leave now.

So, the key points here. The stepdaughter is an adult, 19 years old. Legally, she's an adult, so she's not a minor. The author isn't her parent, so they don't have legal authority to make her leave. The mother (the author's fiancé) is the one who has legal responsibility. The author is considering asking her to leave, but since she's an adult, it's up to her whether she stays or goes. 

Now, the author's reasoning is that they've put time and effort into supporting her, and now they want their space back. They don't care how she reacts. But since the stepdaughter is an adult, the author can't just kick her out. If the stepdaughter doesn't want to leave, the author can't force her unless there's some legal agreement or if they're providing support that's conditional on her leaving. However, in many cases, unless there's a lease or some legal contract, the author might not have the legal standing to require her to move out. 

But the question is whether the author is in the wrong morally or ethically, not just legally. The author is frustrated with the lack of relationship and wanting their own space. However, since the stepdaughter is an adult and living with her mother, the author's fiancé might be the one who's responsible for her living arrangements. The author's fiancé might be the one who should address it, not the stepfather figure. 

So, the author might be overstepping because they aren't the legal guardian. Even if they're living in the house together, the decision to ask the stepdaughter to leave should come from the mother. The author's fiancé might be the one who needs to have that conversation. The author might be in the wrong for trying to assert control over someone who isn't their responsibility. Also, the author's approach of not caring about the stepdaughter's reaction could be seen as dismissive and possibly heartless, especially since she's an adult who might have her own reasons for staying. 

But on the other hand, the author has been supporting her financially and emotionally, and it's reasonable to want some space. However, the ethical issue here is whether the author has the right to make that decision without consulting the mother and considering the stepdaughter's autonomy. Since the stepdaughter is an adult, she has the right to choose where she lives, and the author can't unilaterally decide she has to leave. The author's fiancé's role is crucial here. If the mother is okay with her staying, the author might not have the authority to change that.

So, putting it all together, the author is likely in the wrong because they're trying to control someone else's adult child without legal authority and possibly without considering the mother's role. The author should work with the fiancé to address the situation rather than taking unilateral action.
